data.title: Imre Kertész
data.meta_description: When Imre Kertész was announced as the 2002 winner of the Nobel prize for literature, he received an envelope from the Buchenwald Memorial Centre. Besides a congratulatory note, inside was a copy of a
data.text:
When Imre Kertész was announced as the 2002 winner of the Nobel prize for literature, he received an envelope from the Buchenwald Memorial Centre. Besides a congratulatory note, inside was a copy of a report about the camp’s prisoners, dated February 18, 1945. The deaths listed included his prisoner number: 64,921. “In short,” he told the audience in his acceptance speech, “I died once so I could live. Perhaps that is my real story.”

His literary works drew heavily on his time in both Buchenwald and Auschwitz. It took him 13 years to complete his first and most widely acclaimed novel, Fateless, which was eventually published in 1975 after being rejected by communist censors in his native Hungary.
